text:
I remember the good ol' days when the Super Beard Bros. were playing though this game over many months, and then included Greg on the show, making it into Super Beard Bros. DELUXE -- which also had a few playtroughs (Super Metroid) -- but now things are how they are. But, I'm still just as sad (after more than 2 years) that we lost all those things he brought to the TOVG-network.

Point being; The Completionist was a show that was carried by a *duo*, and that duo splitting, with him kinda dis-respectably being erased from even the slightest mention or call back -- 4+ years into the show (which I followed all those years) -- just makes everything kinda sour. It could've been handled better. (Or perhaps, avoided.)

No hard feelings against Greg or Jirard though. I've even meet Jirard post-split and he is just an as like-able fellow as ever. And Super Beard Bros. is still making great stuff! I highly, highly recommend their L.A. Noire playthrough. Good times are had, and their high-points out-trump even the GameGrumps high-points.


*sigh* What can I say, except that I really, really miss *Greg*.

  -- Very emotional piece for me. Thanks for the upload. :D

text: My childhood, my fantasies and my feelings until I grew up in High School have been dandled by RPGs' Town Themes. I have a very particular love for the sunset atmosphere of Wild Arms. I think that it's rare, but sometimes RPGs game designers have what it takes to be considered film directors. It's a real tribute to Spaghetti Western of Sergio Leone (also for the colors of the ambience) and the music of Ennio Morricone, which have been able to catch the magic of the Western creating an incredible fantasy story.

author: Vegeta

text: @SinJackal I agree that the music has lost a bit of itÂ´s magic. I mean IÂ´ve been sitting here for a while now listening to music from the 80Â´s and 90Â´s, even if itÂ´s music that IÂ´ve never heard before and I canÂ´t really say that about modern games. But there are exceptions is all IÂ´m saying.
author: conny wedin

text: @conny117 Just to expound on that a bit, the only kind of music now that's very noticeable (imo), is the loud, intense music.  There isn't a lot of games who pull off a good song for every area like back in the PS1 era.  So many games had a cool song for like every area in the game.  You could almost straight up listen to a game soundtrack and it wouldn't be boring.  But now, I can't really say that, and I also like all kinds of music.  :(  Music's the one thing that's seemed to diminish a lot.
author: Vegeta

text:
@conny117 That's understandable.  I won't hate on someone for their opinion.  For me it's just, in the past, I noticed that songs sounded really cool, and were nice to listen to.  Now, I barely notice the music at all unless it's in a quiet area with nothing going on at all.  Like the "eerie environment" type area.

Most music now isn't noticeable unless they jack up the BGM volume during events like they did in Dragon Age. . .which got to the point I had to turn down my volume for every fight
author: Vegeta

text: @SinJackal ItÂ´s a different style of music now compared to before. Halo and Mass Effect have great music and they both have music that fits each individual game. Both of those games probably have a much bigger musicbudget than older games, especially Marty OÂ´donnell (Halo) takes gamemusic very seriously. In the end though itÂ´s all opinions, I like both old- and new music.

text: When I think of Wild Arms, I think of the one game that came to me when Final Fantasy 7 wasn't there. I saw this Western game, and it just said to me, "Hey, waiting for Final Fantasy 7?
